summary: This document is an email chain between prosecutors and defense attorneys in the case United States v. Maxwell (20 Cr. 330) regarding scheduling a call to discuss a proposed protective order. The prosecution raises specific questions about the defense's position on naming victims in public filings and requests a hard drive for discovery production.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (AJN). The email discusses protective order issues related to her case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as an individual whose victims are part of the case considerations; the protective order discussion involves individuals who have self-identified as victims of him or Ghislaine Maxwell.

connections.description: The document references individuals who have self-identified as victims of both Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, implying their alleged joint involvement in criminal activity.

events.title: Protective Order Discussion Scheduling
events.description: Prosecution emails defense to schedule a telephonic meet and confer regarding issues relating to a protective order in United States v. Maxwell, following a Court Order from that afternoon.

keyFacts: The prosecution is seeking to schedule a discussion about a protective order to prevent the public naming of victims in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
The prosecution questions whether there is any legitimate need for the defense to reference victims by name in public statements or filings, as opposed to using pseudonyms.
The prosecution requests a 1 terabyte hard drive be delivered to their office for the purpose of discovery production in the case.
The correspondence reveals ongoing legal negotiations about victim privacy and the handling of sensitive discovery materials.
